name: Martinez
proTip: Chill the glass well — this drink loses charm fast when warm.
didYouKnow: The Martinez is often considered a precursor to the modern Martini.

name: Negroni
proTip: Orange peel, not wedge — oils matter.
didYouKnow: Named after Count Negroni, who requested gin instead of soda in his Americano.

name: Whiskey Sour
proTip: Dry shake first if using egg white — texture is key.
didYouKnow: Dates back to naval ships needing a tasty way to serve citrus.

name: Pisco Sour
proTip: Bitters on top are for aromatics — don’t overdo it.
didYouKnow: The Pisco Sour is Peru’s national drink, celebrated every first Saturday of February.

name: Old Fashioned
proTip: Dissolve the sugar fully — it’s a cocktail, not a crunch-fest.
didYouKnow: The term 'cocktail' was originally defined using an Old Fashioned-style recipe in 1806.

name: Tommy’s Margarita
proTip: Use good quality 100% agave tequila — you’ll taste the difference.
didYouKnow: Created in the 1990s by Julio Bermejo at Tommy’s Mexican Restaurant in San Francisco.

name: Mezcalita
proTip: Rim half the glass — let guests choose their heat level.
didYouKnow: The smoky cousin of Tommy’s Margarita, perfect for spice pairings.

name: Cherry Mezcalita
proTip: Balance is everything — cherry can dominate easily.
didYouKnow: A house spin on the Mezcalita, bringing a fruity edge to the smoke.

name: Paloma
proTip: Salt + soda is essential — don’t skip either.
didYouKnow: The Paloma is the most popular tequila drink in Mexico, not the Margarita.

name: Chicago Fizz
proTip: The port adds complexity — don’t sub with sweet red wine.
didYouKnow: Originated in the early 1900s and makes for an unexpectedly elegant highball.

name: Classic Daiquiri
proTip: Serve ice cold in a well-chilled coupe. No fruit, no garnish, no nonsense.
didYouKnow: Invented in Cuba — Hemingway loved his *very* dry.

name: Mai Tai
proTip: Use crushed ice and a mint sprig — it’s not just about taste, it’s theatre.
didYouKnow: Mai Tai means ‘Out of this World’ in Tahitian.

name: Yuzu Negroni
proTip: Chill everything down to avoid bitterness overpowering citrus.
didYouKnow: The yuzu twist brings Japanese acidity to a deep Italian bitter.

name: Reverse Adonis
proTip: Use quality sherry — this drink is all about subtlety.
didYouKnow: A twist on the 1880s Adonis, named after a Broadway show.

name: Spicy Dead Lady
proTip: Don’t overshake — you want sting, not foam.
didYouKnow: The Dead Lady is our own ghostly riff on a spicy Margarita.
